name: Rose Black Spot
description: A common fungal disease of roses and other plants, caused by the fungus Diplocarpon rosae. It weakens the plant by interrupting photosynthesis and causing significant leaf drop (defoliation).
symptoms: Black spots with feathery margins on upper leaf surface

early_stage.description: Small black spots appear on the upper surface of leaves, usually starting at the bottom of the bush.

middle_stage.description: Spots enlarge (up to 1/2 inch). Tissue around spots turns yellow. Lower leaves begin to fall off.

advanced_stage.description: Complete defoliation of the plant. Fungus infects the canes, creating purple/black lesions that harbor spores for winter.

causes: The fungus Diplocarpon rosae, whose spores are spread by water from rain splash or overhead irrigation. The fungus overwinters on infected fallen leaves and stems.

favorable_conditions.environment: Warm, wet, and humid weather. Poor air circulation around the plant. Susceptible rose varieties. Overhead watering that leaves foliage wet for extended periods.

impact.economic_impact: Major issue in ornamental horticulture. Increases maintenance costs.

diagnosis.field_diagnosis: Black spots with feathery edges + leaf yellowing.

prevention: Ensure proper spacing and pruning for good air circulation.
Water at the base of the plant in the morning.
Remove and destroy fallen leaves and infected canes.

chemical_control: Prune and dispose of infected leaves and stems. Apply a preventative fungicide early in the season. Common active ingredients in effective fungicides include Chlorothalonil, Myclobutanil, and Tebuconazole. Neem oil can also be used as a less toxic alternative.

resistant_varieties: Knock Out roses, Drift roses, and many modern shrub roses have high resistance.
life_cycle: Polycyclic. Spores splash up from soil/debris to leaves. Repeat infections all season.
